ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Presentation skills and broad overview of global health topics.
I gained insights on topics including decolonizing health global health, performance/artistic representation in healthcare and deepened my understanding of the social determinants of health.
I learned presentation and synthesis skills. The CAs were really good for this.
I gained a deeper understanding of each of the components of the global health space.

This course is a grand overview of the competencies you have explored through the Global Health Scholars program. Each week is an opportunity to read primary literature and learn about current events related to a particular competency. You also get to hear from guest speakers and faculty, which I found to be particularly helpful for exploring a topic in greater depth.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was a good way to conclude the Global Health Scholars MAP. I do think that it would be beneficial to have some type of project that guided the entire semester, such as a longer research paper or some other deliverable to conclude. Having a capstone of some sort would also have been a great way to tie together the theoretical education with practical application.

I wished the instructors spoke on each module more, rather than only having students present. I enjoyed when guest speakers came in to talk, as it was very enriching / an intimate perspective into the topic at hand, so it would've been nice to get this "expertise" input in the other weeks as well.

I think this class would benefit from being restructured. Most students would have preferred hearing from the professors themselves more, and from delving into new topics. Instead, the course often felt like a summary of everything we already learned in introductory global health classes.
Not very organized
While I appreciated students having the opportunity to run the class, I thought that hearing more from our professors would have given us more to take away.

Strengths: I think the student presentation format is really cool but it would benefit from 50/50 with this and guest speakers
Weakness: It feels a bit fragmented in terms of the competencies. They way the class is structured is that each theme feels disconnected from the others
Strengths  assignment load was great and the feedback was detailed.

The colloquium is a requirement for GHS students and is only for them, so CourseTable doesnt really matter for it. Its a good class, the bonding was great, but too many student presentations. I wish the professors did more of the teaching. The CAs are tough but a good practice to teach synthesis skills! Thank you for them!

The strengths of this course are the instructors and the cohort. The instructors are incredibly kind and supportive, and it's a great chance to get to know the other people in the Global Health Scholars cohort. Weaknesses: though I like the structure of student presentations, I'd prefer more interjections from the professors, since they have so much more knowledge / experience in global health than we do!

Strengths: I love the professors. They are so kind and accommodating and really try to make this class a fun experience. They are incredibly receptive to student input as well. I also enjoyed most of the readings and liked how the presenting group each week sent out notes on the readings in case you didn't have a chance to read through them all in their entirety. The structure of the course is also very flexible and allows you to choose when to submit three critical analyses which alleviates a lot of stress. 

Weaknesses: The class is almost entirely student-taught and I would have appreciated more teaching from the professors since they are so knowledgable. I had already seen some of these readings in other classes for the program so I think it would be beneficial to let students choose a current event or area to apply their knowledge rather than just doing student presentations on a set of readings.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It is a required course for global health scholars
You probably have to take this class, but I would recommend it anyway if they implement some of the changes to make it more solution based and practical learning style.
Yes, absolutely!!
N/A cause mandatory.

I would if you're a Global Health Scholar since it's required. I do think it's a great opportunity to get to know the other cohort members and synthesize all of the knowledge you've learned of global health throughout your time in the program.
This is a requirement for the global health program but I absolutely loved it and think it's a great way to cap off the GHS experience.
